organization.fullName: VA Palo Alto Health Care System

identificationModule.briefTitle: Light Flashes to Treat Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPD)
identificationModule.officialTitle: Treating Sleep Disruption in Teens With Millisecond Light Exposure During Sleep

collaborators.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPD) is a sleep disruption that commonly occurs in teens and manifests as a difficulty in waking up in the morning, going to sleep early enough at night, and daytime disturbances such as depression, fatigue, and restlessness. The purpose of this study is to determine if brief flashes of light, that are scheduled to occur during sleep, are effective in treating DSPD.

armGroups.label: Light
armGroups.description: one hour of a sequence of light flashes (4000 lux, 3 msec, every 30 seconds); occurs during hour immediately prior to desired waketime

armGroups.label: Fake light
armGroups.description: during hour immediately prior to desired waketime, subjects will receive one light flash (insufficient to cause phase shift)

interventions.name: Flashes
interventions.description: one hour of a sequence of light flashes (4000 lux, 3 msec, every 30 seconds); occurs during the hour immediately prior to desired waketime

primaryOutcomes.description: Determined by questionnaire (Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale for Children (depressive symptoms) SNAP-IV 26 (ADHD symptoms)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: at the begining and end of intervention (4 weeks)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Male or female
* Full-time in high school
* primary sleep complaint consistent with delayed sleep phase disorder

Exclusion Criteria:

* sleep only in prone position
* currently taking medications specifically for the treatment of a sleep disorder

references.citation: Zeitzer JM, Ruby NF, Fisicaro RA, Heller HC. Response of the human circadian system to millisecond flashes of light. PLoS One. 2011;6(7):e22078. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0022078. Epub 2011 Jul 8.

Zeitzer JM, Fisicaro RA, Ruby NF, Heller HC. Millisecond flashes of light phase delay the human circadian clock during sleep. J Biol Rhythms. 2014 Oct;29(5):370-6. doi: 10.1177/0748730414546532. Epub 2014 Sep 16.
Joyce DS, Spitschan M, Zeitzer JM. Optimizing Light Flash Sequence Duration to Shift Human Circadian Phase. Biology (Basel). 2022 Dec 13;11(12):1807. doi: 10.3390/biology11121807.

Joyce DS, Spitschan M, Zeitzer JM. Duration invariance and intensity dependence of the human circadian system phase shifting response to brief light flashes. Proc Biol Sci. 2022 Mar 9;289(1970):20211943. doi: 10.1098/rspb.2021.1943. Epub 2022 Mar 9.

Kaplan KA, Mashash M, Williams R, Batchelder H, Starr-Glass L, Zeitzer JM. Effect of Light Flashes vs Sham Therapy During Sleep With Adjunct Cognitive Behavioral Therapy on Sleep Quality Among Adolescents: A Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA Netw Open. 2019 Sep 4;2(9):e1911944. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2019.11944.
